channel.title: [T_R] Wild-Card Importation V.S. Direct Importing
channel.description:
[size=24pt][i][color=red]Wild-Card Importation V.S. Direct Importing[/i][/size]
Hello, and thank you very much for reading this Thread.
As a lot of you may know, I left MoparScape for a brief period of time, but now I have returned. As an apology for my absence, I took the liberty of releasing a 110K.B. Think Tank design for R.S.P.S, which you can find [url=http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,642630.0.html][u]here.[/u][/url]
I hope that someone finds that useful, and now, without further ado, I will give my take on 'Wild-Card Importation V.S. Direct Importing'. I would like to say that I'm not 'dissing' one or the other, as they're both functional, and they both perform their jobs well. I'm simply listing Pros and Cons without bias. Let's take a moment to peak at some lines of code, shall we?
[code=Java] package com.world;
import com.repack.NPC.*; import com.pack.core.Client; import com.pack.player.Player; [/code]
Now, you may look at this and say, "Jack, I don't see anything wrong", or, "These lines of code don't need to be re-written or improved upon".
Let's take a closer look, except we won't need to look at the package directory, so we'll leave that out:
[code=Java] import com.repack.NPC.*; import com.pack.core.Client; import com.pack.player.Player; [/code]
As you can see, one of the Imports is using an asterisk syntax. The use of a Wild-Card Import (the asterisk syntax) denotes that ALL files inside of the corresponding directory shall be Imported. The other two Imports shown, are specific Direct Imports. I'm sure there are users who will argue that there is no difference between the two, but I can assure you, that is just simply not the case. I'm now going to list both the Pros and the Cons of each of the two:
[size=24pt]Pros:[/size]
1. Organization: When you're using Direct Imports - you know EXACTLY which file you're incorporating. This also makes it easier for human eyes to scan, enables you to instantly recognize which file you're Importing, and you aren't including 5 unnecessary files to access one file.
2. Clutter: It's no secret that R.S.P.S. are notoriously messy and unorganized. This is taking a step in the right direction, however, there is another side to this 'plus' as well -- which will be covered very shortly.
3. Familiarity: When using Direct Imports, you will become more familiar with your Source, Classes, Methods, Conditions, and lines of code. The more knowledge you have of what you're working with, the more capable you can become.
4. I.D.E. Knows That Feel, Bro: I've found that some people dislike this function. When using a modern I.D.E, it can and will convert Wild-Card Import statements into Direct Imports. EDIT : ADDED BY HcoJustin : This is IDE dependent. IntelliJ IDEA will prefer direct imports until you reach a certain threshold (Default: 50), or you are in a specified package (Default: javax.swing). It is certainly possible to turn it off, and I'm sure Eclipse and Netbeans have similar features that are easily configured.
6. Build-Time: Although this will most likely cause a large argument, converting Wild-Card Imports to Direct Imports CAN reduce your Build (Compile) time.
[size=24pt]Cons:[/size]
1. Clutter: Previously, when writing up the 'Pros' for utilizing Direct Imports, I mentioned that using them is a step in the right direction - towards organization. However, like I said, there is another ugly side to this. When listing multiple imports, you will start to accumulate a long list of Direct Imports. In this case, a Wild-Card Import would be more practical than a long list of Direct Imports.
2. Absent Class: When using a Direct Import, the specific file you're attempting to Import MUST exist. If you're using a Wild-Card Import, then this is simply not the case.
3. When using Wild-Card Imports, you could run into a Naming Conflict. This usually occurs when two files in the same directory have the same name.
In closing, I would like to reiterate once more... I'm not saying that one of these is better than the other (although I most certainly have my preferences). I would just like to point out that both of these functions have their uses, and both should be utilized according to situations.
[i] ~~~~~Credits~~~~~~
Team_Rocket (Jack): 80% - Written from scratch with both opinions and facts.
HcoJustin: 10% - This user receives credits, because they added on to this Tutorial in a helpful and informative manner. Their edit is highlighted in blue.
Davidi2: 10% - David noticed that I had worded a sentence in a way that could be misread and interpreted in a different manner than it was meant to be.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Knows That Feel, Bro: I’ve found that some people dislike this function. When using a modern I.D.E, it can and will convert Wild-Card Import statements into Direct Imports.
[/quote]
This is IDE dependant. IntelliJ IDEA will prefer direct imports until you reach a certain threshold (Default: 50), or you are in a specified package (Default: javax.swing). It is certainly possible to turn it off, and I’m sure Eclipse and Netbeans have similar features that are easily configured.

There are no conventions directly related to this topic, so it is all a matter of personal preference.[/quote]

item.title: [T_R] Wild-Card Importation V.S. Direct Importing
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

If you’re going to make a tutorial on importing, you should include static imports, because I find them really useful, especially if you use classes purely for constants.

Example: Config class in PI

And I like to use them in minigames. Here’s an example of a minigame constants class I’m working on right now.

EDIT: ignore conventions. Ik the names should be all capital but I hate typing that, I do it at the end. Also make sure they are public and not private.

[code]package server.model.content.minigames.hunger;

public class Constants {

/**
 * Random items that are found on the ground, or in reward boxes
 */
public static final int[] randomItems = {
	4151, 1149, 1147, 1187, 1201, 1215, 1249, 1305, 1319, 1377, 1373, 1434,
	3204, 2491, 2497, 2503, 4587, 3140, 4087, 4091, 4093, 
};

/**
 * Rare items only found in rewardBoxes (E.G crates)
 */
public static final int[] rareItems = {
	11694, 11696, 11698, 11700, 11718, 11720, 11722, 11724, 11726, 11728, 11732,
	4718, 4716, 4720, 4722, 4724, 4726, 4728, 4730, 4732, 4736, 4738, 6585,
	4745, 4747, 4749, 4751, 4753, 4755, 4757, 4759, 4708, 4712, 4714, 565, 560
};

/**
 * Array of all the rewardBox possible objectIds
 */
public static final int[] rewardBoxes = {
	3685, 3686, 3687
}; 

/**
 * Maximum size of the minigame
 */
public static final int SIZE = 8;

}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: [T_R] Wild-Card Importation V.S. Direct Importing
item.dc:creator: @Teem_Rocket Teem_Rocket
item.description:
@Teem_Rocket wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:18, topic:524095”]I have noticed in Eclipse that it will generally speaking import direct imports instead of the wild cards.

I didn’t actually know about the compile time so I learned something today thanks.

Are there any other MAJOR reasons as to why you should use direct imports besides compiling speed?

As I did point out to you though in a class like my player/client/server class I will almost always use wild cards just for the simple fact that it would get messy if I literally placed every single file into it.

Good tutorial though![/quote]

No, there aren’t really any MAJOR reasons. You shouldn’t just take my point of view though. There are a load of people who are biased towards one side or the other. I believe it should be situational because that’s how it was designed to be.

Read full topic

item.title: [T_R] Wild-Card Importation V.S. Direct Importing
item.dc:creator: @Teem_Rocket Teem_Rocket
item.description:
@Teem_Rocket wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:15, topic:524095”]5. Conflict Resolved: When using Wild-Card Imports, you could run into a Naming Conflict. This usually occurs when two files in different packages, or, directories, have the same name. When using Direct Imports, you can avoid this.

This is misleading, you make it sound like you can avoid conflicting class names using direct imports, when really having to use two classes with the same name can’t be fixed at all the way it’s imported. The only difference is, say you had two packages:

  • p1
  • p1.MyClass
  • p1.MyOtherClass
  • p2
  • p2.MyClass
    MyLoaderClass

If in MyLoaderClass you used import p1.* and import p2.MyClass, yes you would run into a naming conflict. However, if you actually needed to use p2.MyClass AND p1.MyClass, you can’t avoid that using direct imports[/quote]

When I read this at first, I mis-read it and got confused. I understand what you mean. You’re correct. I’ll edit it and include you in some fashion. Thank you for pointing this out, I’ve proof-read it and didn’t realize that what I had said could be taken in a different way.

Read full topic

item.title: [T_R] Wild-Card Importation V.S. Direct Importing
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

  1. Conflict Resolved: When using Wild-Card Imports, you could run into a Naming Conflict. This usually occurs when two files in different packages, or, directories, have the same name. When using Direct Imports, you can avoid this.

This is misleading, you make it sound like you can avoid conflicting class names using direct imports, when really having to use two classes with the same name can’t be fixed at all the way it’s imported. The only difference is, say you had two packages:

  • p1
  • p1.MyClass
  • p1.MyOtherClass
  • p2
  • p2.MyClass
    MyLoaderClass

If in MyLoaderClass you used import p1.* and import p2.MyClass, yes you would run into a naming conflict. However, if you actually needed to use p2.MyClass AND p1.MyClass, you can’t avoid that using direct imports

Read full topic

item.title: [T_R] Wild-Card Importation V.S. Direct Importing

item.description:

[b]RS NOTE::
I agree with everything you posted, the only problem is that people don’t give a flying fuck if their work is

  1. read-able by others
  2. organized
  3. reduced compile speed.
    They want the fastest item produced and they don’t care about quality. As long as the donators keep donating why do they need to have an organized structured base and correct packaging?
    [/b]
    tl,dr: people who donate for servers are idiots, usually.

item.title: [T_R] Wild-Card Importation V.S. Direct Importing
item.dc:creator: @Teem_Rocket Teem_Rocket
item.description:
@Teem_Rocket wrote:

im siri:

Eh, would have just been better to directly link to an external explanation. This doesn’t have much relevance to RSPS development and is a pretty small topic.

I’m not arguing with you, and I agree that It’s a confined topic, however. I believe this is a better and more dumbed down explanation than those explained in documents. A lot of our newbie users don’t know where to go to find information like this, so they just browse MoparScape looking for Tutorials and such. If I can help one person learn about this, then I’ve accomplished the goal of the Tutorial. There are also many Bases which are covered up in Wild-Card Imports – often times importing 5+ files just to nab one. Although their projects might be small, and the difference might not be noteworthy, it probably is still having a small impact on Build-time. I agree with you, like I said, but I found a lot of reasons to write this Tutorial, and hardly any convincing me otherwise.

Read full topic

item.title: [T_R] Wild-Card Importation V.S. Direct Importing
item.dc:creator: @Teem_Rocket Teem_Rocket
item.description:
@Teem_Rocket wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:3, topic:524095”][quote author=Teem_Rocket link=topic=642638.msg4327617#msg4327617 date=1373201744]4. I.D.E. Knows That Feel, Bro: I’ve found that some people dislike this function. When using a modern I.D.E, it can and will convert Wild-Card Import statements into Direct Imports.
[/quote]
This is IDE dependant. IntelliJ IDEA will prefer direct imports until you reach a certain threshold (Default: 50), or you are in a specified package (Default: javax.swing). It is certainly possible to turn it off, and I’m sure Eclipse and Netbeans have similar features that are easily configured.

There are no conventions directly related to this topic, so it is all a matter of personal preference.[/quote]

I’ll be sure to include this. Thank you for your contribution.

Read full topic
